headline: Sugar Cookie Icing
description: This quick and easy sugar cookie icing is the best topping you can choose, as it uses ingredients you most likely already have on hand. Use whatever food colors you like!

video.description: Take your cookies up a notch with this top-rated sugar cookie icing recipe. It's easy, impressive, and it comes together super quickly with ingredients you probably already have on hand. Add food coloring if you'd like to switch it up!
video.name: Sugar Cookie Icing

name: Sugar Cookie Icing

recipeInstructions.text: Stir together confectioners' sugar and milk in a small bowl until smooth.
Beat in corn syrup and almond extract until icing is smooth and glossy. If icing is too thick, add more corn syrup.
Divide into separate bowls, and add food colorings to each to desired intensity. Dip cookies, or paint them with a brush.

review.reviewBody: easy to work with, dries hard enough to stack

When I made it the icing was too thick and very sticky so I added a small amount of milk and quickly became to runny which sucked because I had made about 100 sugar cookies for Christmas and didn't have enough ingredients to make more however the icing did taste very good.
it was good.
Good consistency and flavor. After a few days it got pretty hard, but that shouldn‚Äôt happen if you eat them fast enough.

I made this recipe as written, as written the icing is very thick. I thinned with milk to get to a pip-able consistency. I was worried about using too much so added a very little bit at a time and do not have an exact measure. I used this on some extra basic gingerbread men so it worked for what I needed. If I made this again I would probably use equal parts of milk and corn syrup to thin.

Perfect recipe! I grew up with almond extract in my birthday cake frosting so I love the almond extract flavor that adds a hint of extra sweetness and complexity. You can easily swap out for your extract of choice. I also have successfully used oat milk in this recipe since I was out of dairy milk. This icing is easy to thicken or thin depending on your preference and easy to double or triple as needed. Definitely my go-to recipe for sugar cookies!
I followed recipe and turned out great!

You can use any extract. We prefer lemon. I usually use more milk, too - 4-6 tsp, depending on the consistency I want. I don't increase the corn syrup amount. Have used this one for years and it's made my sugar cookies famous among friends and family. Thanks!
Way too thick, even after adding extra milk and corn syrup. And overall bad taste. Can't recommend this recipe.
This icing is pretty thick. I found that milk thinned it better than corn syrup. It was very glossy and made pretty cookies.

When I initially made this recipe, I doubled it but it was so thick that I wouldn‚Äôt have even been able to spread it onto my cookies without breaking them. I added more milk to thin it out (the corn syrup is more to give it a glaze when set). I finally got it to a consistency that I prefer to use as I pipe my icing. I made another single recipe right after but used 1 tbsp of milk instead of 2 tsp and it was spot on!
First time I think success. Easy recipe. Still working on my piping technique.

Wow....I followed the recipe to maybe a quarter tsp on corn syrup and it came out beautiful! Set up great and I piped through a baggy. I left them out on the counter to dry overnight and they are certainly hard enough to be stacked! I think the others who said it was a sticky recipe just didn't let the corn syrup milk and powdered sugar settle into each other long enough by stirring it smooth. Thank You so much for this recipe!
It was very greasy and did not pipe at all, slid off my cookies. I even added extra powdered sugar to save it, won‚Äôt make again
Excellent! This is my go to icing for Christmas sugar cookies!
Absolutely excellent. My daughter was amazed she could make the same type of icing found on Starbucks' Christmas Cookies.
excellent recipe
Good icing. As suggested by another reviewer I used 4 t milk, 1 t vanilla, a dash of salt, & 1 t light corn syrup. Good taste and shiny. üëçüèº

I doubled the recipe exactly as written and it was thick enough for edges and detailing. I then made another doubled batch and added a little more milk to thin it and used that for flooding the cookies. It was enough for 14, 4‚Äù cookies with some left over. I used the almond extract and let the cookies dry for 24 hours on a cookie sheet. When I first made the icing as written I thought it was too thick but let the stand mixer continue to mix for a couple minutes and the icing ended up being perfect.

I used the basic starting point of 1 cup confectioners sugar and 2 TBSP milk (I needed a bit more than 2 tsp) and added some strawberry jam in place of the corn syrup to make a strawberry flavored icing for Valentine's Day cookies. Worked pretty well.
VERY sticky and a bit hard to frost the cookies. I did like the almond flavoring, however.
Used lemon extract instead of vanilla. Wonderful recipe!!
This worked well except I had to add water as it was too thick. I'm not fond of almond flavoring so I used lemon extract and it was wonderful!
Needed way more milk and corn syrup but I just kept adding till it was the right consistency. Thanks!

I use this for my sugar cookies. It dries shiny-ish. Weirdly over time it gets more dull. I think the measurements are off. I've never been able to make this icing without adding more syrup and a bit more milk. It's unworkable in any capacity at these measurements. I also find it dries hardish but not hard enough to stack.

Had to tweak recipe to make it work, 2 teaspoons of milk? More like to 4 to 5 teaspoons. After I tweaked the recipe it was okay. Measurements are key to a recipe so probably best to ensure your measurements are more accurate

This will be my go-to cookie icing from now on. The taste is so much better than traditional Royal Icing. Once it is completely hardened, it holds up very well; even the flavor keeps well. My cookies were left out overnight before I could consider them sturdy enough to stack. Then they were frozen and thawed more than once, and survived being shipped across the country; after more than TWO weeks, they were still beautiful and delicious! I have given this only four stars, because it is quite difficult to work with until you get the hang of it. One batch makes a very small amount of icing, and it is no where near the consistency needed to pipe and fill cookies, so it requires a lot of thinning. But use caution, adding more corn syrup to thin it out as the recipe states will cause the icing to never fully set. The trick here is to keep the corn syrup:milk ratio close to the same. Once you get it right, though, they dry to a beautiful, shiny icing! I also added extracts and oils to make almond, lemon, and orange flavors!
didn‚Äôt work. Became a sugary doughy paste instead of a smooth liquid. Do not use this recipe as written
it was easy and simple.
Great consistency. Taste great. Easier to apply if you let it sit a bit

My ten-year-old and I really enjoyed working with this icing. We did substitute the almond extract with lemon juice since we were making lemon cookies. Read the other reviews on how to best mix ingredients. The taste was really nice. We used the paint brush method with a wider brush and this gave nice control in the decorating process. Will use this recipe every time.
I have using this icing recipe for years. Separated into small bowl with food coloring, it is perfect for small children and painting cookies. Very versatile, drys hard and shiny!!
One of the better icing. Easy. I use this over and over.
We loved it!
I like that it is shiny but it tastes pretty awful, very sweet
This recipe does not work. It is much too dry and needs a lot for milk. Someone needs to rewrite it so that it works!!!!
this icing i the best and easy it's definitely ygo to frosting

Full disclosure: I am not a sugar cookie fan. I do not think any icing could fix the blandness of cutout cookies. They are wonderful fun to decorate the the kids always like them, so I make them a few times a year. This icing was way easier to make and more forgiving than royal icing and tasted a bit better. I love how shiny it is. The only downside is how quickly you need to decorate before the icing sets to the point where it won't grab sprinkles. That can be a good thing (it takes longer to ice the cookie and let kiddos decorate it, thus drawing out the fun time) or a bad thing (I can't ice multiple cookies and let the kids decorate while I concentrate on my own masterpiece).

I made this without light corn syrup and it turned out great. For a decorating idea: add drops of food coloring to the frosting, but BARELY MIX IN. Then, duck the cookie in the frosting and fling to shake off any extras. This makes an amazing marble pattern!
So much better than royal icing. Experiment with the recipe. I also added vanilla.
This is a simple icing recipe that dries within a few hours. I personally like the hint of almond extract for my sugar cookies.
Perfect as written!
I used 3tsp of milk and it turned out perfect for what I needed. Will definitely be using this recipe again

Used 5 teaspoons milk, 1 teaspoon vanilla extract, and 1 Tablespoon light corn syrup. Added drops of food coloring, swirled with a toothpick and then dipped the cookies to get the the dye look. Very fun! Can‚Äôt wait to eat!!!
Easy to make and spread on your cookies! I dries quickly
We LOVE this icing recipe! We don‚Äôt care for the taste of almond extract so we leave that ingredient out but we‚Äôve been making this recipe for 4 years now and it serves us well every time!
Everyone else was right about needing to add more milk which wasn't a big deal but I really didn't care for the taste. Was really disappointed.

I have severe food allergies... like... put me in a coma on life support and a very long recovery. Reminder to tell people you are using almond. Some grab a sugar cookie and assume they are safe. This is an awesome recipe! Lemon instead for us. Thank you!
Delicious.
Was very good! I had to add a little extra milk and I didn't have any almond extract so I used vanilla. It was very very good. This will be my sugar cookie icing recipe from here on!
I LOVE this recipe. Doubled it and added a little extra milk and syrup. It hardened up nicely once it set on the cookie.

This was my first time to make iced sugar cookies. It was a Christmas cookie baking with my 6 year old grandson and it was great. He loved the flavor. They are not bakery quality but the memories were treasured
I have struggled to find a great icing recipe...this is perfect! Turned out Sidney and hard just how I‚Äôd hoped!

I‚Äôve read the reviews after I made the dough. I was nervous. However, it was unfounded. These came out perfect. I let the dough sit in the fridge overnight. Even the last batch made from the recycled scraps came out great. This will me my go to for now on
Followed exactly as is!

Made this for my Christmas cookies this year and it was fantastic. Used vanilla in place of almond just because the kids prefer it and needed at least 3 more spoons of milk to thin it down. Best icing I‚Äôve ever used. Dries shiny and hard within about 30 minutes.
tasty, easy, glossy icing
The icing was perfect. I followed recipe exactly except a little more milk. I also added Anise extract to the icing for the wreaths.
Well it sets up great and looks pretty, but it doesnt taste great. Rather just use frosting.

AWFUL! I followed the recipe and it was VERY stiff. I added a good 2T of corn syrup and it was still too stiff. We couldn‚Äôt spread it on the cookies with a SPOON, much less a brush. I gave up. We‚Äôll eat the cookies without icing.

This makes wonderful cookie icing once you get the correct measurements. I tried making this recipe exactly as written, but the icing wasn't nearly thin enough, so I doubled the milk and light corn syrup and then it was perfect.
I add a little more corn syrup just so it‚Äôs smoother and easier to spread. Will never use another sugar cookie icing. This is it!

I'm not sure how these amounts can be right? Tried mixing 2 tsp milk with 1 cup sugar and it was one big clump. Had to keep adding milk just to get it to stir. Have to admit this is my first attempt at cookie icing so it could be a rookie mistake somehow. The color did stay bright and the flavor was fine with the addition of almond extract.

Great recipe, tastes awesome. I doubled the ingredients except halved the almond extract(my kids weren‚Äôt keen on its taste which is why I doubled it) turned out yummy! Kids went crazy.
My picture won‚Äôt upload ):
So fun. I doubled the recipe and have a ton of frosting left over!
Perfect recipe for beautiful and delicious cookies!

There has to be something wrong with the measurements in this recipe. Two teaspoons of milk mixed with 1 cup of powdered sugar will never reach a smooth consistency. I had to keep adding more teaspoons of milk until I lost count, and still ended up with a thick, gooey mess. What a disappointment.

Sugar Cookie Icing by JBS BOX. Spongebob cookies - Marie -from King Arthur; Nanny, this icing. Separately, I wasn‚Äôt so sure we had a hit tastewise; together, oh my! I used marshmallow slices then blue M & Ms, then black gel for pupils (& eyelashes).

This is a keeper recipe. Not only was it tasty but it's visually very pretty. It's smooth and shiny almost like glass after it dries, it looks gorgeous with colours swirled in. A must have for creative baker types, you could find a lot of uses for this.
Made without corn syrup very good.

I don't know what I did wrong, because I followed the recipe, but it didn't make a liquid. I added more corn syrup and milk until it was thin enough as suggested in the video, and the tast was absolutly discusting. I would never make this again, I couldn't eat it.

First time using icing instead of frosting for my sugar cookies, did have to add more milk to get powder sugar "smooth". Got to perfect consistency to use pastry brush, which is much quicker than frosting with a knife. Definitely my new go to for cut-out cookies.

Made icing for the very first time and this recipe is great , I did read other reviews and decided I should add 2 extra teaspoons of milk and it worked perfectly, the icing set in a few minutes and has a nice glaze over the cookies ! It‚Äôs my daughters 7th birthday and she sure will be a happy girl !! Thank you for sharing the recipe.
I use this recipe very regularly. Everyone always asks for the recipe. I have to at least double the corn syrup and the milk. The icing tastes bests once it dries completely.

I doubled the recipe and like an idiot used tablespoons and not teaspoons for the milk. I was like ‚Äúthis is so runny‚Äù! I just added a bunch more powdered sugar and a little more vanilla until the consistency looked okay and it worked out great!
I made this icing. It was easy to work with and made my Easter cookies look great! This icing did not take away the flavor of the cookie, either. This recipe is a keeper for me. Thank you!

I made this exactly as the recipe specified and it was dry and crumbly! I adjusted as suggested by adding extra corn syrup, ended up with at least triple the amount called for. The flavor is wonderful, but proportions are WAY off!
Super cute and glossy! Tastes great and my kids loved it! Needed a little extra milk and corn syrup but way better than the pilsbery store bought frosting.
used the ingredients, I would make more of it, perhaps double the size because my daughter likes a lot of icing on her cookies!
I followed the recipe exactly. This was so sticky and not at all spreadable.
It was Delicious! But I had to make a few adjustments like I had to add a little more milk and a little less extract. But other than that it was all good
The frosting was perfect for my galaxy themed sugar cookies. Simple, and tasty!

Great icing and definitely better than using Royal Icing. I've already made multiple batches of icing and it's turned out great. I always double the recipe. I'm not sure why the recipe doesn't call for more milk because there is no way to decorate with it as is.
Awesome!! Went perfect on Soft Christmas Cookies by Georgie Bowers. Making it again! :)
The icing came out tasting like cough syrup. Beautiful icing, awful flavor.
Added a bit more milk. Worked really well!

I made a double batch to have enough to ice 70 cookies.I followed the recipe exactly and the icing was so stiff I could not work with it.So I had to triple the amount of milk and corn syrup called for to make it spreadable enough to paint my cookies.I wonder if teaspoon should not be tablespoon instead.
I already used this recipe couple times and turned great every time! Easy to cutout and bake! Yummy for my Tammy

This is the only icing I use for my sugar cookies. I use a teaspoon of almond extract, and everyone loves this icing! They say they are all spoiled now and won't eat "real" royal icing. It's great for flooding, but still manageable.
Amazing! Put this on gingerbread cookies and everyone loved it!
Easy to work with and dried hard and shiny.

This recipe did not work for me. There‚Äôs not nearly enough milk to get a smooth consistency. And the taste was really not good‚Äîmade the cookies almost inedible. I made some royal icing with pasteurized egg whites the next time instead, and it was way better.
I didn't make any changes to it. It was so hard I could store it let alone spread it on cookies. I ended up having to go buy prepare cookie icing which worked out fabulously.
It was a bit thick to work with on the cookies, and is taking a long time to set up/dry.

This is an excellent frosting for sugar cookies. I did make a few changes and also suggest one I‚Äôll be making for next time. It says 2 teaspoons of milk, I needed about 4, 2 wasn‚Äôt even close. I would also only add 1/2 of the almond extract. It‚Äôs overpowering and a little too sweet. But the consistency of the frosting is spot on, it doesn‚Äôt get hard like a lot of others and it‚Äôs easy to apply.
Excellent, easy and no need for any changes !

This is not a perfect recipe BUT it's a perfect starting point for Sugar Cookie Icing WITHOUT meringue powder (which is hard to find). Just know you'll be adding more milk and water. I've made this several times and it's extremely thick as is. 

I automatically add 2 additional teaspoons of milk for each batch following this recipe. Then I use a spray bottle of water to change the consistency. 

(Don't add more corn syrup to this to make it thinner! Doing this makes it way too sweet and sticky. I just add milk and water)
 This recipe makes a small amount- enough for each color. So make a big batch if you want and then seperate to bowls for adding color or to make your different consistencies. 

Changes: add 1/2 teaspoon of Vanilla & 1/2 teaspoon of Almond Extract and a dash of Salt.
When you want a very bold color -add 1 teaspoon of Cream of Tartar. When you what a bright solid white outlining batch of icing, don't add Vanilla Extract ( the brown color will make the icing cream colored). Instead, just do that batch with (clear) Almond Extract and the 1 teaspoon of cream of tartar. 

If it's the first time making total icing for decorating, watch some YouTube videos to learn the consistencies you want before hand!

The recipe is versatile as other reviewers have suggested by adding a different flavor instead of the almond. I liked the suggestion of another reviewer about adding the powdered sugar into the milk. I did the opposite and didn‚Äôt think it would turn out by the way it was clumped up. It wasn‚Äôt until I added the extract and corn syrup that it smoothed out. It was very flavorful and I love the glossy finished look. I ended up making another batch because it didn‚Äôt look like one would be enough.

This icing was perfect! The almond extract was an unexpected pleasure. I was really hesitant in adding it but I‚Äôm so glad I did. I received so many compliments on the al of flavor. I wouldn‚Äôt change a thing!
